Authors: Putri M.R., Luke J.Y., Sela S.T.
Title: Critical success factor in blended learning for English training: A systematic literature review
Affiliations: Language Center, Hotel Management Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Language Center, English Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Language Center, Computer Science Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Putri, M.R., Language Center, Hotel Management Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Luke, J.Y., Language Center, English Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Sela, S.T., Language Center, Computer Science Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The rapid development of technology has impacted many aspects in education world. The technology development has challenged how education was brought to learners. The traditional way may no longer fit the demand. This research aimed to investigate the critical success factors in blended learning for English Training. Systematic literature review was established to reach the conclusion. 30 journal articles published in 2013 to 2017 were examined to gain the results and findings. The result showed there were 11 key success factors in delivering the English training by blended learning. The most critical factors were the course design of blended learning, the instructional model of blended learning, and the teaching learning method in the blended learning course. It was suggested in the future to emphasize the research on the various designs of blended learning, the tools for the online sessions, and the suitable teaching learning method in the blended learning course. © Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: Enterprise resource planning; Learning systems; Teaching; Blended learning; Critical factors; Critical success factor; Instructional model; Key success factors; Systematic literature review; Teaching-learning method; Technology development; Curricula
Funding Text 1: This research paper was funded by the research grant from Bina Nusantara University.

Title: Capturing students' critical thinking skills in English for academic writing course: A case in information system students
Affiliations: Language Center, Hotel Management, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Language Center, Computer Science, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Putri, M.R., Language Center, Hotel Management, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia; Sela, S.T., Language Center, Computer Science, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta Barat, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Writing has been regarded as the most difficult language skills since students in Indonesia were not familiar with this skill in the early and middle education level. On the other hand, in higher education level the students should produce a thesis to complete their study. Facilitating the students to be ready for the thesis writing, English for Academic Writing course was delivered to the students. Research-based teaching method was implemented in the course in order to help the students improved their writing skills as well as the critical thinking skills. The purpose of this research was to investigate the impact of the research-based teaching method toward the students' critical thinking skills in writing. Case study was implemented to reach the conclusion. Fifty (50) Global Class students majoring in Information System were observed to gain the result. Questionnaire result was used to support the observation data. The result showed there was improvement in students' critical thinking in academic writing after joining the class. Further, the result also found the method may help the students sharpen their 21st Century skills such as collaboration and communication. © 2018 Association for Computing Machinery. Copyright 2010
Author Keywords: 21st Century Skills; Critical Thinking; Research-based Teaching Method
Index Keywords: E-learning; Information systems; Information use; Teaching; 21st Century Skills; Academic writings; Critical thinking; Critical thinking skills; Higher education; Observation data; Teaching methods; Writing skills; Students

Authors: Asalla L.K., Putri M.R., Dedy Pradipto Y.
Title: The critical success factor of E-learning in higher education: A systematic literature review
Source title: Proceedings of 2017 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2017
Affiliations: Information System Department, School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Language Center, Hotel Management Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Psychology Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Asalla, L.K., Information System Department, School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Putri, M.R., Language Center, Hotel Management Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Dedy Pradipto, Y., Psychology Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Technology has changed the way people live their life as well as the way they study. People can study whenever and wherever based on their availability and interest. The growth of e-learning in higher education has developed rapidly to accommodate the issue. This paper aimed to find out the key success factors of e-learning in higher education. Systematic Literature Review was conducted to reach the finding. 54 journal articles were examined to gain the result. The examined journal articles were published between 2006 up to 2016. The result showed that there were 17 key critical success factors of e-learning in higher education. The most critical factor was the IT infrastructure or the learning management system (LMS) followed by e-learning tools and e-learning models. The result also revealed that there was a paradigm shifting in learning process from traditional way. It was suggested the future focus of this research area to emphasize the implementation of LMS in e-learning so that e-learning in higher education can be implemented well. © 2017 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Enterprise resource planning; Information management; Critical success factor; CSFs; E-learning models; Higher education; IT infrastructures; Key success factors; Learning management system; Systematic literature review; E-learning

Authors: Sela S.T., Luke J.Y., Putri M.R.
Title: The expectation of faculty on english language skills study through online learning
Affiliations: Language Center, Computer Science Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jalan Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Language Center, Hotel Management Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jalan Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Sela, S.T., Language Center, Computer Science Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jalan Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Luke, J.Y., Language Center, Computer Science Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jalan Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Putri, M.R., Language Center, Hotel Management Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jalan Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: This paper focuses on the expectation of faculty on English training and the English language skills they want to improve through online learning. There are two kinds of English language skills to aim, the skills related to academic writing and TOEFL preparation. To identify the required skills to be improved aligned with the expectation, questionnaires have been spread through online to collect data from faculty members in all majors. Collected data consists of faculties’ identification, the learning difficulties, the expectation and the required skills. The result shows the required skills that are possible to be learned through online and the expectations of the faculties that are realistic to be fulfilled. The result will be used to develop online English language trainings to improve the required skills of faculty. © 2018 ACM.
Author Keywords: Academic Writing; English Language Training; Expectation of Faculty; Online Learning; TOEFL Preparation
Index Keywords: Surveys; Academic writings; English languages; Expectation of Faculty; Online learning; TOEFL Preparation; E-learning
